body:
I meant that if we get clean master and apply parameters swapping + force float point operations for ActiveSupport durations:

``` ruby
distance_in_minutes = ((to_time - from_time)/60).round # --- remove
distance_in_minutes = ((to_time - from_time)/60.0).round # +++ add
```

your tests from #5710 will be passed without any additional changes. I prepare example: https://github.com/avakhov/rails/commit/cb632e56820ce242cb1e6d775dc48b33546273bb

```
~/m/github/rails/actionpack(1.9.3-p0-ff)[5710-another]$ ruby -Itest test/template/date_helper_test.rb 
Run options: --seed 44240

# Running tests:

......................................................................................................................................................................................

Finished tests in 6.350915s, 28.6573 tests/s, 67.3919 assertions/s.

182 tests, 428 assertions, 0 failures, 0 errors, 0 skips
```

I'm sorry. AS means AsctiveSupport. If you use `59.seconds` actually you get ActiveSupport::Duration object. It's rather tricky wrapper about Fixnum (`2.yeas` is Float however). `distance_of_time_in_words` works well for time intervals, because `time1 - time2` is Float and `59.0/60 == 0.98333`, but is broken for AS distances because of 59/60 == 0.

We just should force using float arithmetic to get your tests work proper. Parameters swapping helps leap years trick to work right.
